text:
Xindice path handling is rather inconsistent in embedded mode.  Specifically I
refer to the -d flag in xindice and to system.xml.

For example, my current directory is "/home/me/work", and my Xindice install
directory (XINDICE_HOME) is "/usr/local/Xindice".

When I run embedded Xindice from an application in /home/me/work the dbroot path
is looked up relative to the current working directory (or absolute).

When I run "xindice ??? -l -d config/system.xml -c /db ..." from /home/me/work,
system.xml is looked up from /home/me/work/config/system.xml but the dbroot is
evaluated from /usr/local/Xindice !  Thus, it finds /usr/local/Xindice/db rather
than /home/me/work/db.

The big problem here is that the command line tools base the relative path in
system.xml from XINDICE_HOME while an embedded app uses the current working
directory.  The workaround here is to use an absolute path in system.xml, but
this is unattractive for obvious reasons.

Further, the command line tools don't seem to like absolute paths for -d. 
'xindice lc -l -d $HOME/work/config/system.xml -c /db' fails because
/home/me/home/me/work/config/system.xml can't be found.  The relative path seems
to be prepended to the given absolute path!

This behaviour has been replicated on Darwin 6.6 (OS X 10.2.6) and linux
2.4.18-26.8.0smp.
creator: andrew.e.white@motorola.com
vgritsenko@apache.org
text:
There were many changes in path handling in embedded mode. There are changes in
tools also, there is separate XINDICE_HOME and XINDICE_DB_HOME environment
variables now. I'm closing this bug as it does not describe current CVS anymore.

If you have suggestions/issues with current CVS, please re-open this bug or
submit new one.
